subject: Re: estimating effort for Junit
msgSnippet: ... [...] ... Last week, I wrote a somewhat complex SQL query generator for an quite ugly database structure, and I ended up with about 1000 LOC (in 2 classes:
messageBody:
> svaddiparti wrote:
>
[...]
> > At the granular level i.e per test case per method, is it possible to
> > come up with lines of code (LOC) for JUnit code. If so what are the
> > parameters on which the LOC for a particular test case depends on.
> > This muct include teh mock classes also.

Last week, I wrote a somewhat complex SQL query generator for an quite ugly
database structure, and I ended up with about 1000 LOC (in 2 classes: Lots
of linear lists of mappings from objects to tables and columns), which are
tested by more than 2000 LOC of unit tests (97 test methods). The test cases
resulted from a painstaking application of the category partition method
(see Beizer, Ostrand, ...) because I really wanted to cover "all cases".
Altogether, the 1000 LOC cost me 1.5 days (including design and lying in bed
at night thinking about the design); the 2000 LOC another 3 hours of writing
(on paper) the relevant cases and and 5 more hours to implement (much
copy/paste, I admit) and repairing the bugs I found [no TDD: I wrote the
1000 LOC a bloc].
But your mileage may vary (as does mine! - this was an especially lucky
piece of code).

In other cases, the amount of test code is less than half of the tested
code.

My gut feeling tells me that the Halstead (or some comparable) complexity
should somehow correlate with a satisfying test suite ... maybe something
researches useful/useless things like this :-)

Regards
H.M.Mueller
